text.text_translated: Managers often try to make their **feedback** (which means comments and advice about someone's work) sound more positive by putting negative comments between two positive ones. However, when this becomes a normal way to give **feedback**, employees might start to think that the positive comments are just a way to hide the bad news, so the positive **feedback** loses its value. Instead, positive **feedback** should not just be used to make negative comments softer, but it should be given to support and encourage good work.
